Description: Scaraboid in the shape of cowroid in glazed composition, probably mould-made; back decorated with a circle containing a cross in the centre of the surface; underside bearing hieroglyphic inscription with a Maat feather and neb-basket signs symmetrically arranged on both sides of a central nefer-sign.
Curator's comments: This scaraboid was not seen by us. Cowroids are relatively rare in the corpus of scaraboids from Naukratis. Such shape was produced locally in the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming), since several examples of cowroids of the same type were discovered at the site (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 52). Though the hieroglyphic signs on its base could have just some magical value, it seems plausible that this is a cryptographic inscription. The formula 'Amun/Amun-Ra is my lord' can be written in many different ways (Drioton 1957, 20-26). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 109)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.089) (phase 3)
